title: Between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2018, will an armed group from Nigeria engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Nigeria?
preds: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer nec odio. Praesent libero. Sed cursus ante dapibus diam. Sed nisi. Nulla quis sem at nibh elementum imperdiet. Duis sagittis ipsum. Praesent mauris. Fusce nec tellus sed augue semper porta. Mauris massa. Vestibulum lacinia arcu eget nulla. Class aptent taciti sociosqu ad litora torquent per conubia nostra, per inceptos himenaeos.

According to ACLED, from January 1 - March 24, 2018, Fulani ethnic militias have deliberately killed 447 civilians in Nigeria's Middle Belt.  This is part of an ongoing campaign to expel Christian settlers.

417 civilians (mostly Christians) killed by Fulani militias in Nigeria's Middle Belt so far in 2018, according to the ACLED project.  This is part of an ongoing campaign to force Christian farmers out of the Middle Belt, a geographic area of central Nigeria.
ACLED documents 306 civilians (mostly Tiv Christians) killed by Fulani militias so far in 2018.
Boko Haram not as strong, and Niger Delta militants very unlikely to engage in this type of mass-scale killing.
Nigeria seems to be moving in the right direction.
Fulani militias systematically killing Christian farmers in the Middle Belt resulted in 1,000+ civilian fatalities in 2014 and came close in other years.
Boko Haram kills a few hundred people at a time in regular attacks.

Boku Harum is the most lethal insurgency in the world.  Competing groups within the BH sphere are beginning to amass resources through targeted operations that have financial gain rather than intimidation/terror as the primary motive (kidnapping young girls).  The Nigerian government and BH symbiotic relationship depends on money coming into the country from military, NGO and UN-backed initiatives.  Guaranteed 1000 deaths.

Although Islamist groups represent a significant theoretical threat in Nigeria there is little to suggest their gaining sufficient traction to successfully mount a campaign of the magnitude necessary to meet the criteria. There is little evidence either that these groups are strategically valuable to anyone who might conceivably fund them to an extent necessary to do so. There does remain the possibility that displaced Islamists may game the region for diffusion purposes.

Update from my previous forecast - Jan 18, 2018 08:10PM:
After revisiting some of the news data that was used to determine a 90% probability that 1000 civilians would be killed in a conflict I found some error's and unconfirmed data.  The reported fact that 30% increase last year to 13,508 deaths was from an older source dated from 2015, more current information is reporting a decline in the number of deaths from Boko Haram since their tactics have changed to suicide bombings.
https://www.crisis.acleddata.com/nigeria-september-2017-update/
https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/world/nigeria-boko-haram/
Since the Boko Haram have become less effective in inflicting massive civilian casualties I am removing 60% chance that 1000 civilians will be killed by a Boko Haram campaign 90% - 60% brings the percentage to 30% The other factors from my previous report are valid so I will continue from here. A new factor that perhaps has more potential than any other to create a series of events that will result in over 1000 civilian casualties is the care that refugees are receiving by the Army while living in displacement camps.  There have been several occurrences of mass killings either by accident or intention of civilians that are under the charge of the Nigerian Army,  The real total of civilian casualties seems to be hard to confirm since many of the deaths are either at the hands of or due to neglect by army personnel. 
https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2018/country-chapters/nigeria These refugee camps have become a nightmare for the displaced, death from disease and starvation are common place.  The military has reportedly abused these people and many have died while under protection either from accidental or other means.  From the figures it would appear that several thousand civilians have died in these camps and this should satisfy the parameters of the question under "policies that knowingly result in widespread death". In one camp alone over 1000 deaths occurred in 2016.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/23/refugees-die-starvation-illness-nigeria-camp-bama-boko-haram
The situation has gotten worse as supplies dwindle and disease continues to spread as the Government seems unconcerned by these deaths.  Cameroon is also deporting 100,000 refugees, sending them back to Nigeria after years of abuse adding to the stressful life threatening situation.
https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/09/27/cameroon-mass-forced-return-nigerian-refugees
http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/04/hunger-amplifies-infectious-diseases-millions-fleeing-violence-boko-haram
The danger of mass civilian death due to abuse or neglect while interned in refugee camps that have been created from the years of war and conflict, seems to be a probable cause for over 1000 civilian deaths.  I am adding back into the probability 45% that these camps will result in over 1000 deaths from  "policies that knowingly result in widespread death" 30% + 45% = 75%
+6% feel like the number part is easy to count and rising but the semantics might be the tripping up point
Slightly increasing this forecast due to the huge amount of Farmers and other civilians being killed by fulani during january so far. If this rate keeps up, it would take less than 10 months.
It will definitely happen it’s economy is too unstable
Even though 1000 people is not a lot in Nigeria (considering the size of the population) but i can't see where the internal conflict would come from before the end of the year

Good background article from the beeb... while Boko Haram May have killed almost 1000 last year that was across multiple events and wouldn’t come close to resolving this question as yes. Boko Haram a mostly spent force (aligning with Daesh? How quaint - should have gone with al Qaeda) resorting to suicide bombings like all girlie men do when they lose the initiative. Nigeria benefiting from US arms/advisors. That leaves Biafra -simmering for two generations...but with oil prices likely to stay high, a certain amount of $ can be spread around.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-42735414

I need to do more research here but seems worth at least 50% or better.  - lh http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-42735414?ocid=socialflow_twitter
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-42735414 Boko Haram reportedly mounted a total of 150 attacks in 2017, an increase on the 127 attacks it is said to have mounted the previous year.
The data show a growing overall emphasis on suicide attacks.
In Nigeria, the group increased its suicide attacks from 19 in 2016 to 38 in 2017, with Cameroon experiencing a similar increase.
Suicide attacks were the most common method of attack in the Nigerian city of Maiduguri, which continues to be the epicentre of the insurgency, whereas armed assaults were more common elsewhere.
At least 967 people were reportedly killed by Boko Haram attacks in 2017, an increase on the previous year when 910 deaths were reported.
The highest concentration of fatalities in 2017 was in Maiduguri, which has seen its population double to two million in recent years as people flee Boko Haram violence in rural areas.
Elsewhere in Nigeria, there were also high concentrations of fatalities in the localities of Magumeri, Konduga, Damaturu and Mubi.
For years, critics have accused the Nigerian military of not properly equipping its soldiers to deal with Boko Haram.
This may change in 2018, with the US agreeing to sell weapons to Nigeria.
Until then, the group looks set to remain a significant threat, says BBC Africa Security Correspondent Tomi Oladipo.
Nigerians would not tolerate a 1000 plus death toll. Would destabilize the government

Update from my previous forecast - Jan 16, 2018 09:41PM:
several assumptions based on current reported news sources: 
reported increase in civilian death toll in the region, 30% increase last year to 13,508 deaths so the potential for 1000 casualties from one campaign is plausible 100% in 2015 Boko Haram killed over 1000 in one simple campaign the chances of repeating this act would be 100% since this accomplished their goals 
The Boko Haram is currently escalating attacks with no concern for civilian casualties. -20% reduce by 20% since world attention from news and the U.N. is now focused on the slaughter of civilians, there may be some resistance to enact 2015 style campaigns.  +5% Add 5% because the Government is involved in campaigning for re-election and stopping the slaughter of civilians is not on the radar. My original 20% reduction assumed that the government was actively concerned about the killings of civilians, new reports I have read lead me to believe that there seems to be no active concern about civilian casualties from the government. +5% A recent active threat of Fulani herdsmen attacking civilians because of lack of resources has added another deadly component to this area that increases the potential for civilian mass casualties.  The struggle for resources from climate change increases the threat of civilian mass casualties by 5% The potential of mass slaughter of civilians will continue in the area unless there is interdiction.

several assumptions based on current reported news sources:
in 2015 Boko Haram killed over 1000 in one simple campaign the chances of repeating this act would be 100% since it accomplished their goals
reduce by 20% since world attention from news and the U.N. is now focused on the slaughter of civilians, there may be some resistance to enact a 2015 style campaign.
reported increase in civilian death toll in the region, 30% increase last year to 13,508 deaths so the potential for 1000 casualties from one campaign is plausible
Unrest between Christian and muslim populations is growing.
Book Haram mostly spent force. Military getting more organized... low risk of 1000 deaths...

There was, is and will be (for an unforeseeable period of time) violence in Nigeria - but the possibility, that one single campaign or event will cause the aforementioned death toll is surprisingly low, because the nigerian population is hopelessly quarreling.
A PROCESS FOR POLITICAL CHANGES WILL COME FORTH.
With the elections approaching, the Nigerian Government will seek accommodation with the armed groups to minimize attacks
With Boko Haram, the chances of this happening are quite high.
